Award.AwardTitle: Prediction of Dynamics at the Micro-Tool Tip for Micromachining when using Ultra-High-Speed Spindles

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports research on mechanical micromachining by providing a new framework for accurate prediction of three-dimensional dynamic response at the tool tip. The research objective is to gain fundamental understanding on tool-tip dynamics by combining experimentally-determined spindle dynamics, accurate models of rotating micro-tool dynamics, and the non-ideal motions arising from the spindle and tool-attachment errors. The specific research approach involves (1) the use of specialized dynamic testing methods for experimental modeling of spindle dynamics, (2) the use of three-dimensional linear elasticity techniques to model dynamics of rotating micro-tools, and (3) the use of laser interferometry to measure error motions of ultra-high-speed spindles. Subsequently, the models for spindle and tool dynamics and error motions are integrated to obtain tool-tip dynamics. The research will also involve experimental validation of the combined tool-tip dynamics predictions for different micro-tools and under different operating conditions. The educational objectives include enhancing the existing manufacturing curricula, and attracting students to manufacturing through pre-college outreach activities.

The research will offer a comprehensive modeling capability for predicting dynamic behavior at the tool tip when using ultra-high-speed spindles, and will thereby facilitate fabrication of parts with precise micro-scale features in a predictable and efficient fashion from metals, polymers, and composites. Such parts are in high demand from many industries, such as medical and energy-conversion devices. Although micromachining technology has come a long way in the last few years, a wide-range industrial adoption has not yet been realized. One of the main reasons is the lack of thorough understanding on process characteristics, specifically process mechanics and dynamics. This project will provide an effective approach for characterization and predictable utilization of micromachining processes. The industrial relevance of the project will be ensured through our collaboration with two leading spindle companies, which will enable rapid transfer of research findings to industry, and thus, will positively impact advanced manufacturing efforts in the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to predict the dynamic response at the micro­tool tip when using ultra-­high­-speed (UHS) micromachining spindles. The research objective is to test the hypothesis that the dynamic response at the micro­tool tip is determined mainly by the coupling between the combined UHS­spindle/micro­tool dynamics and the non­ideal motions arising from the spindle and from the tool­attachment errors. In this project, the speed-dependent dynamic response at the micro-tool tip when using UHS spindles are obtained. The dynamics of the UHS spindles is critical to the micromachining process as the bandwidth of the micromachining forces can reach up to 20 kHz. To facilitate the high bandwidth dynamic characterization of UHS spindles, an Impact Excitation System (IES), to provide repeatable impacts, is used. The dynamics of the tool is analytically modeled using our in-house developed, computationally efficient numerical technique. This numerical technique, when coupled with the experimentally obtained speed-dependent dynamics, helps in predicting the overall dynamics at the micro-tool tip.

As proposed, we addressed this objective by performing experimental modal analysis to obtain FRFs, and use multi­-degree-of-freedom curve­fitting techniques (based on orthogonal polynomials) to derive an experimental model of the spindle dynamics. The impact excitations have been delivered using a newly developed miniature impact system up to 20 kHz excitation bandwidth under controlled force magnitudes and with high repeatability. For the current project, we advanced the already developed dynamic modeling technique (the 3D spectral-Tchebychev technique) to include the rotary effects. The precision and effectiveness of the modeling approach is performed by comparing the results (natural frequencies and mode shapes of the micro­tools) calculated by the presented technique to the ones found by a 3D­FEM analysis.

The presented experimental methodology to obtain the UHS spindles enables accurate determination of the speed ­dependent dynamics of the miniature UHS spindles within a 20 kHz bandwidth in the form of FRFs with uncertainties less than 3% for the entire frequency bandwidth (less than 1% for the resonance regions.) The technique was demonstrated by modal testing a UHS air­ bearing spindle at different speeds (up to 170,000 rpm) and collet pressures. A measurement and analysis approach to calculate radial throw of tool-axis at the tool tip is validated with the use of custom made carbide tool-blank. The predicted magnitude and orientation of radial throw complied within 3% and 1 degs. with the measured values, respectively.

Finally, the predicted tool-tip dynamics are validated by direct measurements (using the presented experimental methodology). The validation studies performed shows that the presented coupling approach is highly effective in accurately predicting the tool-tip dynamics in micromachining applications.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this project is to predict the dynamic response at the micro­tool tip when using ultra-­high­-speed (UHS) micromachining spindles. The research objective is to test the hypothesis that the dynamic response at the micro­tool tip is determined mainly by the coupling between the combined UHS­spindle/micro­tool dynamics and the non­ideal motions arising from the spindle and from the tool­attachment errors. In this project, the speed-dependent dynamic response at the micro-tool tip when using UHS spindles are obtained. The dynamics of the UHS spindles is critical to the micromachining process as the bandwidth of the micromachining forces can reach up to 20 kHz. To facilitate the high bandwidth dynamic characterization of UHS spindles, an Impact Excitation System (IES), to provide repeatable impacts, is used. The dynamics of the tool is analytically modeled using our in-house developed, computationally efficient numerical technique. This numerical technique, when coupled with the experimentally obtained speed-dependent dynamics, helps in predicting the overall dynamics at the micro-tool tip. As proposed, we addressed this objective by performing experimental modal analysis to obtain FRFs, and use multi­-degree-of-freedom curve­fitting techniques (based on orthogonal polynomials) to derive an experimental model of the spindle dynamics. The impact excitations have been delivered using a newly developed miniature impact system up to 20 kHz excitation bandwidth under controlled force magnitudes and with high repeatability. The precision and effectiveness of the modeling approach is performed by comparing the results (natural frequencies and mode shapes of the micro­tools) calculated by the presented technique to the ones found by a 3D­FEM analysis. The validation studies performed shows that the presented coupling approach is highly effective in accurately predicting the tool-tip dynamics in micromachining applications.
